table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe myself, my family and my circle of friends and acquaintances, in very simple single phrases.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can sum up difficult contents orally with no effort, and give a precise rendering of important details in the process.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: During a presentation, I can reply to difficult questions, and defend my viewpoint.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In a fluent, effortless manner, and with relevant details, I can talk about ideas and experiences (past and present), and develop and present these in an interesting way.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: Through word stress or emphasis in sentences, I can highlight finer shades of meaning, e. g. when telling stories or anecdotes.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: With no preparation, I can talk about the issues and retell the contents of texts, films, interviews and media reports, in a detailed way.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can structure an argument systematically, stand up for key points, and underline relevant details.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can give presentations (that I have prepared beforehand) in an interesting and lively manner, and awaken an audience’s interest in an issue. I can also highlight special aspects; draw attention to open questions; respond to objections or interjections; and round off my contribution with an appropriate conclusion (e. g. project descriptions; product presentations).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe complex facts or situations in a clear, very detailed way.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can narrate and talk about my experiences (past and present), my ideas, my job area and about texts read, with fluency and in great detail.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In a clear and structured way, I can describe the most varied sequences or processes, explain rules, and give more complex working (or other) instructions to enable others to act accordingly.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can sum up the contents of texts, commercial films, interviews, or reports in such a way that my audience will be clear about the main points.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: If I have the chance to prepare extensively, I can hold and convincingly argue a view, giving the advantages and disadvantages of various options and relating these to each other.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can formulate my intentions, plans and goals with precision; I can explain and give reasons for my point of view about topical issues.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: Regarding my areas of interest I can develop and give presentations (prepared in advance) that are well structured and lingustically clear, so that my audience can clearly recognise the main points, along with important supporting details. I can also react spontaneously to relevant questions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In a spontaneous and largely fluent way, I can give clear, detailed descriptions and accounts of very many topics related to my fields of interest and of specialisation.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can narrate what I have experienced, got to know or thought up, in a spontaneous, largely fluent and detailed manner.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In simple connected phrases and sentences, I can describe and explain charts or diagrams.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can expand on complex themes with ease, structuring my talk well and adapting it to the needs of my actual audience.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In really short, prepared single phrases I can state where I live.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In very short, prepared sentences I can tell people what training I go in for, or what my line of work is.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can introduce someone (e. g. a speaker, or a guest), using short, well-learnt sentences.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reproduce short texts that I have listened to several times or that I may know by heart (e. g. rhymes/poems, slogans, songs, pop-songs).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reproduce numbers, e. g. telephone numbers.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: Using several simple phrases and sentences, I can talk about and report on habitual and planned activities (e. g. my interests, schedule of work, daily schedule of activities, my weekends).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can talk about events and personal experiences (present or past, e. g. concerning my training or work), if I can prepare such statements.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe places familiar to me, in a series of simple phrases (e. g. where I live, my place of work, where I go on holiday).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe my training, or my present or most recent job, in simple phrases and sentences.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can give a short, simple, prepared presentation on a topic with which I am familiar. I can reply to simple questions that are directly relevant if I can ask for some questions to be repeated.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: With the help of words or illustrations known in advance, I can prepare and tell simple stories and describe events or processes.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reproduce short sections from texts read or listened to, using several simple sentences.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe objects, devices and their function, in simple ways.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reproduce simple calculations (e. g. 3,5 by 2 equals 7), and describe simple shapes.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can give an account of what I have heard, seen, or experienced, provided these areas and topics are familiar to me; I can also describe my feelings and reactions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can give factual descriptions (e. g. concerning the weather, accommodation, school, work) and outline sequences of events in situations familiar to me (e. g. events in the course of a day; celebrations; job-related activities).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can give well prepared uncomplicated short presentations, making things easy and interesting for my audience.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can present my opinions, plans, intentions and goals, and give simple reasons.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe pictures, and tell stories with the help of keywords or illustrations.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can narrate the content of a book or film, and say what I think of it.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reproduce short factual texts in a simple way, while keeping to the structure of the original text.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In a simple but structured way, I can describe, explain or sum up job-related facts and sequences of events (or things related to my area of specialisation, e. g. of a scientific, technical, or business nature).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can say hello and good-bye, and introduce myself or someone else.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can ask for people’s names, ask simple questions about where they live, about objects and about spare-time activities, or answer such questions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can ask other how they are; I can say how I am.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can ask very simple questions that are part of shopping, if I can confirm what I want by pointing to things or with the help of other gestures.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: When I‘ve been unable to understand I can say so, ask what was said, and request a repetition or explanation.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can ask for something; say thanks; and apologize.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can spell aloud names and addresses that I am familiar with.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can deal with numbers, e. g. ask for a telephone number/the time of day/the price of goods; I can also reply to such questions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In everyday situations and in role play, I can name simple objects, give simple instructions, and take simple roles.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can participate in simple exchanges (e. g. on matters concerning family, friends, training, work and spare time activities). I can also show interest in what someone else says to me.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can state what I like and dislike, and ask others about their likes and dislikes.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can go shopping; in post offices and banks I can ask for things (e. g. for stamps; when changing currencies), while sometimes making things easier for myself by pointing to things, or other gestures.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can state my opinion on a given topic, in simple words.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can say if I am agreeable about something: if necessary, I can make a different suggestion.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can ask for directions; I can explain how to get somewhere, with the help of a map or a plan.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can fluently spell aloud names and addresses.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In direct communication or on the telephone I can talk about intentions, and arrange appointments or meetings.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can take a role in a dialogue or a simulation exercise (e. g. in situations of everyday or working life).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In simple exchanges between two persons, I can take the role of language mediator and ‘hand on‘ simple information regarding family, friends, training, job and spare-time activities.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can start a conversation on topics familiar to me, keep it going, and end it.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can express feelings such as surprise, joy, sadness, interest or indifference; I can react to feelings expressed by the other person(s).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can linguistically manage everyday situations (e. g. in shops, banks or firms), though I may have to ask people to repeat or explain a word now and then.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can manage most situations that arise in connection with travelling (e. g. bookings, orders, complaints).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can ask, or answer, questions about familiar topics, without preparation.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can voice my opinion on familiar topics in exchanges, discussions and meetings, and give reasons. I can also agree or politely disagree, and make other suggestions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In a self-presentation or interview, I can give information about myself, my personal and my working environment.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can make phone calls in standard work-related situations, if the other person speaks slowly and clearly. Occasionally I need to ask them to repeat or to rephrase.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can take a role in a simulated everyday situation or a work-related one, and I can even manage to improvise.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In simple everyday situations or situations related to training or work, I can fill the role of language mediator between two persons, and ‘hand on‘ essential information.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can participate in exchanges on many topics of everyday life, on my work or my areas of interest, in a fairly fluent and spontaneous way. I can also clearly express my viewpoint, my feelings, intentions and wishes.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In discussions on topics with which I am familiar, I can state and explain my viewpoint clearly and defend it; look critically at various other suggestions; and go into details when arguing against some such suggestions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can communicate with native speakers with such a degree of spontaneity and fluency that neither long pauses nor misunderstandings will arise.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In an exchange (e. g. in an interview) I can take the initiative, develop and argue lines of thought.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can influence teamwork and how it progresses, by means of questions and other oral contributions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can manage linguistic situations where the main goal is to negotiate a solution to a conflict (e. g. a quarrel, a complaint).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reliably communicate detailed information taken from a variety of sources, both in direct speech and on the telephone.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In role play or simulated scenes, I can take a longer role to design and enact, including improvisation.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In exchanges on topics familiar to me, I can take the role of language mediator and communicate, sum up and explain information for the benefit of the two interlocutors.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can express myself spontaneously and fluently in longer exchanges, about almost any topic (training, work, personal life, social and scientific subjects); only very rarely do I need to search for words.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In discussions and meetings I can state and explain my ideas and suggestions convincingly, give clear reasons, and sum up and illustrate results, even when topics are abstract, complex and not really familiar.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In discussions, debates and meetings I can reply to questions, and react effectively and spontaneously to other persons’ comments and arguments.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can begin an exchange, keep it going, and end it, taking the roles of speaker and listener in turn. I usually understand jokes and allusions and can react accordingly.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In interactions I can express my feelings in ways that are differentiated and appropriate to the situation in hand; I can perceive the other person’s feelings and react accordingly.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can freely participate in interviews, both in the role of interviewer and in that of interviewee. I can develop issues under discussion fluently and without help from outside and enlarge on them; I can deal well with interjections or unexpected comments.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can reliably communicate all kinds of complex and detailed information for others to use, both in direct exchanges and on the telephone.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In role play or simulated scenes, I can take a longer role to design and enact, including improvisation.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In discussions and meetings, I can take the role of language mediator and communicate, sum up and explain information for the benefit of interlocutors; I can also explain arguments and viewpoints with precision.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can take part effortlessly in any conversations or discussions in the most varied situations, including with native speakers of various different origins.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In formal discussions, meetings and negotiations on complex topics, I can assert myself by arguing clearly and convincingly, being almost on a par with native speakers.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I am familiar with idiomatic expressions and colloquialisms, and I am aware of their connotations. When occasionally I have difficulty expressing myself, I can reformulate in ways that are hardly noticeable to other people.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can recognise finer shades of meaning, and can react to them in a differentiated and effective manner.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In interviews, I can take the role of interviewer or of interviewee, and can interact convincingly and very fluently. I can structure speech, with next to no drawbacks relative to native speakers.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In discussions, meetings and negotiations, I can take the role of language mediator. I can communicate with precision complex information and arguments between interlocutors; explain viewpoints; and express finer shades of meaning.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can recognise words and very basic phrases known to me, in very simple spoken exchanges concerning familiar topics (e. g. about my family, circle of friends, meals, leisure activities).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow very simple stories, accounts and songs, with the help of pictures or facial expression and gestures.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: When I listen to very simple texts on topics familiar to me, on the radio, a CD or other audio media, I can recognise some words and phrases.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In audiovisual presentations, I can recognise what very simple texts are about that concern topics familiar to me.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand very simple short questions (e. g. someone asking for my name, my address, about my spare-time interests).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand and follow very simple short instructions and explanations (e. g. instructions for work, safety instructions, directions).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand very simple news and messages (e. g. on an answering machine).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand numbers, price tags, and simple expressions of time.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can recognise what simple conversations are about, if the topic is familiar to me and people speak clearly.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can recognise the gist of a simple story, of a simple song text, or of a short scenic performance.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can skim short and clearly spoken texts on audio equipment for essential information, provided that these relate to foreseeable everyday things (e. g. the weather forecast) or to familiar (e. g. job-related) subject areas.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow the main information content of TV broadcasts about events, persons, places and sequences of events, with the help of the pictures.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand the most important points of instructions, questions, and information (or requests for information) related to everyday situations, training and vocational situations.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand simple explanations (e. g. how to get from A to B on foot, or with public means of transport).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow the main lines of simple descriptions of processes and work schedules (e. g. safety instructions, instructions for use, preparing dishes).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can grasp the main point of short, clear, simple announcements (e. g. at the railway station, at an airport, on the shop floor) and of communications.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I understand what is said to me in everyday spoken exchanges. Sometimes I need to ask the other person to repeat what they have said; or ask them if I have understood correctly.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow the main points in interviews, reports and talks.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand the gist of stories, narratives, acted scenes, and songs.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow the gist of what native speakers say when they use standard dialect and speak clearly about things familiar to me.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow the gist of radio broadcasts and audio recordings if they concern current affairs or one of my interests.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow films and TV programmes if pictures give strong support to content, and if the language used is clear and uncomplicated.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow more detailed instructions, questions and information in everyday situations, or in training or professional contexts, and when travelling.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand technical information, e. g. instructions for use regarding technical devices and tools used in everyday life.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand well the main points of statements that are more complex linguistically and content-wise (e. g. reports and presentations) if standard dialect is spoken and if the topic is one that interests me.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: Within my special area of knowledge or my professional situation I can follow a lecture or a talk, as long as the contribution is clearly delivered.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow spoken interaction between native speakers well, provided they are using standard dialect and I am reasonably familiar with the topic.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow radio and TV programmes regarding current events or familiar topics. While listening I can pick up not only information, but also speakers’ viewpoints and positions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow the plot of commercial films and of plays well, provided standard dialect is spoken for the most part.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand messages, announcements and communications spoken in standard dialect and at normal speed.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow interlocutors on the telephone provided the content is familiar.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow technical information, e. g. more detailed descriptions of familiar products, functions, and services.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow complex speech on the most varied topics (e. g. reports and presentations, including those given by native speakers), provided standard dialect is used, in the main.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow a complex talk or a conversation relatively easily, in my own field of specialisation or my professional or working life.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow lively everyday talk, spoken interaction, discussions and debates between native speakers well, even when the topics dealt with are not very familiar to me.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow radio broadcasts and various audio recordings well, while picking up more complex information and relationships at the same time, as well as recognising attitudes and opinions that are implied (not openly stated).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can easily follow artistic performances (e. g. in TV programmes, in films, the theatre, on video or DVDs) that have a high percentage of colloquial speech and idiomatic expressions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I understand any unexpected questions, objections or information posed or given by my interlocutors even on a poor quality telephone line.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow lectures, talks and presentations on the most varied topics (both general and specialised topics), including those that make use of idiomatic phrases and unfamiliar terminology.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow lively discussions and debates with a high percentage of idiomatic phrases, with no particular effort.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow everyday exchanges between native speakers without any difficulty at all, even if they speak very quickly, use many colloquial expressions or phrases, and / or with regional features of speech.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can follow media offerings that are of interest to me (on the radio, on TV, in the cinema, theatre, on video, DVDs…) with ease, while recognising some finer points about language or content at the same time.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand complex technical information, e. g. specifications concerning products, the functioning of technical apparatus, and services.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can recognise names, single words, groups of words and very simple phrases or sentences in prospectuses, on posters and notices, and in newspaper reports.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand really simple stories with pictures.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand very simple short notes and written messages in or about everyday situations (e. g. explanations about directions; postcards, emails, notes of telephone conversations).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand really simple printed forms (e. g. such as can be found at immigration or when registering at an hotel) to the point of being able to give details of myself (e. g. my name, place and date of birth).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand really simple instructions given by a computer programme or computer game.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand really simple working instructions regarding my training or my field of work.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can find and understand essential information contained in simple everyday texts that refer to familiar situations (e. g. prospectuses, brochures, menus, posters, timetables, advertisements).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: If I am familiar with a given topic, I can understand simple stories, poems and dialogues in the main, even if I do not know all the words.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand simple non-fictional texts (e. g. descriptions, instructions for use, safety regulations) if there are pictures or graphics that support the content.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand short or simplified texts from literary sources, such as can be found in periodicals or magazines for language learners.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand simple messages and texts in the internet, in computer programmes and computer games.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand short simple personal letters, postcards, emails and SMS’s.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand the main points in simple job-related standard correspondence that follows a frequently used schedule and refers to familiar situations (e. g. enquiries, orders, confirmation of orders).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I understand working instructions in my training and on the shop floor/my place of work, and written notes about other kinds of work that I do.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can gather essential information from simple newspaper or magazine articles that are clearly structured.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand non-fictional texts that are simple, were written for a wide readership, and are about topics related to my interests or my field of specialisation.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand longer, relatively simple literary texts with no great difficulty, if I am familiar with the subject (e. g. simplified texts, modern light fiction).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In clearly structured argumentative texts I can recognise the main conclusions to be drawn from them.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand personal letters, postcards and emails in which feelings, wishes and experiences are being described.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand clearly structured job-related standard correspondence that refers to familiar situations (e. g. complaints, demands for payment) to a degree that enables me to react adequately.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand well written and well structured instructions for use.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can locate information in various longer texts or parts of texts that I need to discharge a particular task.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I understand articles (e. g.in magazines and in specialised professional periodicals) on topical issues that I am familiar with: I can also recognise what points of view are taken by the writers of such articles.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: When scanning long, fairly demanding non-fiction texts, I can extract essential information to decide whether more detailed reading is worth my while, for my own purposes.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: Though I may not understand every word, I can read many literary texts in the original, as long as they are written in modern standard register.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can recognise stylistic devices in literary texts (e. g. images).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand personal correspondence with no effort.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand job-related correspondence that refers to a field of work familiar to me, with no effort (e. g. letters, notes, emails).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can skim a non-fiction text for relevant information (e. g. a handbook that may accompany a technical device, or a computer programme), and find (and understand) a suitable explanation for a problem.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand long, complex instructions as well as detailed recommendations or regulations, as long as they refer to a field of knowledge or activity that I am familiar with.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: If I can look up a few words now and then in a dictionary, I can understand texts which are more demanding (content-wise and linguistically) - though I may not really be familiar with the topics of such texts.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand the most varied long, complex texts (e. g. newspaper articles, specialised texts, brochures, web sites), including attitudes and opinions only indirectly expressed or alluded to, provided I can read difficult passages more than once.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: When reading literary texts I can understand content easily; over and above content, I can recognise implicit messages and positions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can identify and understand the meaning of stylistic devices that occur in literary texts (e. g. symbols, parables, alliteration).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand any kind of personal or job-related correspondence.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand in detail long, complex instructions relating to new technical apparatus or procedures, even outside my field of specialisation, provided I can read difficult passages more than once.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can recognise how various types of text differ from each other in intention, register, form and structure, as well as in the linguistic means employed (e. g. a personal letter compared to a formal letter; a report compared to a piece of commentary; a poem as opposed to the text of an advertisement).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand linguistically demanding long texts in detail (e. g. articles in newspapers and in the internet, specialised texts, brochures). At the same time, I can grasp and critically interpret fine stylistic differences and implicit meanings.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can read manuals and specialised periodicals with ease.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can read literary texts of any genre in their original version, with no effort.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can recognise and understand dialect features in texts, as well as historically or socially conditioned forms of language.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can easily understand idiomatic phrases as well as stylistic devices such as metaphors, irony, satire, ambiguity and puns, and relate these to the text’s effect.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can understand in detail contracts, regulations and minutes (e. g. minutes of a meeting; of technical tests).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write very short single phrases or sentences about myself, my family and my circle of friends and acquaintances.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write simple phrases about what I do (for a job), and where I live.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can complete a “wanted” poster, with short items (such as the colour of my eyes, height, my age).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write simple messages (e. g. text messages/SMS’s, emails, picture postcards, birthday cards).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write lists (e. g. shopping lists, lists of products), and fill in simple forms (e. g. registration forms, order forms).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can copy words and sentences correctly.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: Given a word list, I can form simple sentences and write them down.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: When searching the internet, I can formulate simple keywords to look for information.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write about my family, my environment, my training and my present activity.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe where and how I live, in simple phrases.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write a short, simple text about a personal experience (e. g. in my training or my job).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In simple phrases, I can report on an event and write about what happened when and where (e. g. an accident, a meeting).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write picture postcards, short letters and emails to communicate messages, to thank people, to apologize or to answer questions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write a short note (e. g. where I am going, with whom I’ll be staying, what I need, when I’ll be back).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: With the help of words, illustrations or film material provided, I can write a short, simple story; I can describe what happens, and sequences of events.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write reports and simple articles about events and experiences of a general and job-related nature. Those texts may be intended for various print media, home pages, or for other personal or vocational uses.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write simple stories, essays and creative texts.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can describe personal impressions that narrative texts or books, films or plays have made on me.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write simple descriptive texts about basic facts or tasks relating to my field of specialisation (e. g. technology, science, business studies, language, literature).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write simple personal correspondence as well as job-related standard texts such as letters, emails, telephone notes, memos.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write a simple CV, and a simple letter of application.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can introduce myself, e. g. by writing a letter to a family who will be my hosts, and to a future employer.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can react to advertisements and enquiries, and can give or request additional information.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can use the new media for personal communication (e. g. participating in chats), and as a basis for written texts (e. g. enquiries via the internet/by email; writing short versions of texts in web sites that are factual and job-related).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can sum up the gist of a text if it contains information relating to a topic that I am familiar with, and if the starting text is clearly structured and not too complex. The source text may be in my mother tongue (2), or in the target language.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write various types of texts (e. g. articles and reports) on familiar subjects which are related to my interests or work, and state my personal opinion.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write in a well-structured way about events, experiences and about my own ideas.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write personal letters and emails about topics of everyday life or which belong to my area of interests. At the same time, I can respond to stories, accounts, feelings or viewpoints of the other person or persons.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can clearly formulate job-related correspondence and minutes that refer to areas of work or tasks which are familiar to me; I am aware of the rules governing the various types of text.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can discuss viewpoints in a text (e. g. in essays, readers’ letters, or reports), highlighting the essential points, supporting an argument with the help of facts, and take account of other lines of argument.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write clear, easy to follow summaries of notes; minutes (e. g. of talks or meetings); or accounts of technical tests.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write fact-based reviews and commentaries, e. g. of films, written texts, on technical innovations.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can sum up texts that refer to a topical issue or a subject that is one of my interests, in a way that is clearly structured. Source texts may be in my mother tongue (1) or in the target language.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: After spending some time and effort on a subject, I can write about a complex topic in a clear and well-structured way, underlining the salient points.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write about experiences in a clear and easy to follow manner; I can present these to my readers and raise their interest by way of exact description and graphic detail.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: On my own or in a team, I can write creative texts, e. g. poems, narrative texts, parts of a play, texts for the advertising industry.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can adapt to a particular group of addressees by choosing a particular type of text (e. g. emails, formal letters, narration, report, detailed and full discussion, a specialised article). For my texts I can choose a register (or style) appropriate for the readers in question.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can sum up in writing information from various different sources (newspaper articles, special subject texts or periodicals, the internet) in a meaningful and clearly structured way. I can follow basic rules and conventions of quoting sources.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write my own interpretations of literary texts and other works of fiction or art, supporting my viewpoints (e. g. with the help of quotations from the original text).

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can sum up complex technical or otherwise specialised texts in a way that these can be followed and understood by non-specialised readers. The relevant source texts may be in my mother tongue (1) or in the target language.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write with ease and linguistic effectiveness on topical issues, in the shape of readers’ letters, articles or essays.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write original linguistically effective fictional texts, e. g. short stories, dramatic scenes, lyrical texts.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write personal and formal letters with ease. I can also express criticism in a polite way.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: In job-related correspondence I can describe complex facts of a case with ease, being mindful of the conventions of a given type of text.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can write with ease well structured, very readable reports, statements and scholarly texts, on complex subjects which are part of my professional field or related to my course of study. For this purpose I can put together information from various different sources (periodical articles, specialised literature, the internet), which I can connect in meaningful ways; I can cite sources according to the recognised conventions.

table.name: block_desp_descriptors
table.title: I can sum up non-fiction texts, literary texts, films and TV reports in a clear, well-structured way, and comment on these from my own point of view. Source texts, films or reports may be in my mother tongue, or in the target language.

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: knowledge

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: comprehension

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: application

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: analysis

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: synthesis

table.name: block_desp_taxonomies
table.title: evaluation

table.name: block_desp_skills
table.title: listening

table.name: block_desp_skills
table.title: writing

table.name: block_desp_skills
table.title: reading

table.name: block_desp_skills
table.title: spoken interaction

table.name: block_desp_skills
table.title: spoken production

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: A1

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: A2

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: B1

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: B2

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: C1

table.name: block_desp_niveaus
table.title: C2

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Reading on this level means being able to understand single words, groups of words or very short simple phrases that are encountered in everyday life.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Understanding short, linguistically and argumentatively simple texts encountered in everyday life, in one’s training or in occupational roles. Essential information contained in such texts is understood. As opposed to A1, short connected sentences can be understood at this stage.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Understanding texts that are about frequent topics of everyday or work-related life which the reader is familiar with. As opposed to A2, sentence structures and vocabulary of these texts are more complex and wider; topic areas are more varied, and include current affairs and events (among other things) as well as the description of emotions; texts are longer.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Learners can write various types of text about a series of topics that are familiar or of personal interest. Compared to Level A2, vocabulary and linguistic structures are much more extensive, so that a wider range of topics can be covered in writing. The purpose of written pieces can be seen and understood clearly, even though mistakes may still occur, in the areas of spelling, vocabulary, grammar and structure.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Written texts about topics of immediate everyday concerns are linguistically and intellectually simple; set phrases are often used, and statements are joined together with the help of simple conjunctions such as and / but / because / first / then / afterwards / later. In comparison to Level A1, texts are longer.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Written texts about some few everyday topics consist of single words or of set phrases.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Texts encountered on this Level are about topics one is familiar with, either in spoken interaction or via the media; speakers use standard dialect clearly and at medium speed. As opposed to A2, topics are more varied and also include current affairs. The meaning of some unknown words can already be successfully deduced from the context.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: In everyday situations that learners are familiar with, the gist of statements can be understood in spoken interaction and when reproduced via the media. Clearly articulated speech is necessary; learners may ask for repetitions, or listen to audio texts several times. As opposed to A1, speaking speed is somewhat faster; there are fewer pauses for thought.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Single words, phrases and very simple sentences concerning familiar situations can be understood in direct communication as well as via the media when people speak slowly and clearly. Pausing for thought is needed. On this Level, listening to the same message or speech unit several times is standard procedure.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: To be able to understand longer texts that present greater difficulty content-wise, sufficient prior knowledge is required in a given subject. Standard dialect is used, and there is no very disturbing background noise. As opposed to Level B1, these are linguistically more demanding contributions on a variety of topics which may go beyond the learner’s immediate range of interests. On this Level, another challenge is to be able to pick up details when texts are spoken at greater speed.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Clearly structured factual texts as well as creative texts can be written by learners at this Level, on topics that are of importance in our society: texts that sum up information, that explain various viewpoints, and that correspond to recognised types of text (e. g. diary entries, inner monologue, readers’ letters). As regards summaries of texts, the degree of difficutly in source texts will correspond to Level B2 in reading comprehension skills. As opposed to Level B1, topics here go beyond immediate personal everyday concerns; they are clearly structured; vocabulary and linguistic structures are extensive enough to allow learners to express their purpose of writing well.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Texts on almost any topic, with a degree of difficulty (regarding content or language), are understood well, even if their structure is not evident and some details are not clearly stated but only implied or hinted at. As opposed to B2, texts may present linguistic features of certain geographical areas or of (careless) colloquial speech (as is often the case in films and in TV serials), without impeding learners’ understanding much. Speaking speed corresponds to normal everyday speech.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Subjects from the most varied areas of knowledge and experience can be dealt with in writing, in a detailed, precise and appropriate way. As opposed to Level B2, learners on this Level can linguistically adapt their writing to a given target group. Vocabulary and linguistic structures are extensive enough for difficult aspects of facts or circumstances to be expressed clearly, for easy communication.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Understanding any kind of spoken text presents no difficulty any more. As opposed to C1, speech is understood even when it contains more pronounced regional features. Listening comprehension on this Level corresponds to that of educated native speakers.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Texts of all possible varieties and types are written with ease, due to learners’ extensive vocabulary, and to their mastery of linguistic structures and stylistic devices. As regards style, texts are developed and presented that are interesting enough to facilitate readers’ understanding (even of difficult lines of thought) and which help them retain details. As opposed to Level C1, this is a linguistic and intellectual level which is usually reached by educated native speakers only.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: On this Level, readers can understand texts (non-fiction or literary texts) that clearly allow them to recognise a writer’s viewpoint, and which are about topics that are relevant to life in our society. Such texts may be used to extract essential information; or they may be scanned, to gain a first impression of them. As opposed to B1, these are linguistically more demanding texts with a much greater vocabulary, with more complex linguistic structures, and on a greater variety of topics.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Understanding most texts in detail is practically no problem – even texts that are difficult content-wise or linguistically. As opposed to Level B2, learners can now consciously differentiate between formal and informal speech, and can recognise finer stylistic qualities, e. g. in a literary text. Texts can be understood even though readers may not be familiar with a given specialisation. Dictionaries are used only if the exact meaning of a word cannot be inferred from the context, or to clarify detailed nuances.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Gaining an exact understanding of texts of all kinds, which presents not the least difficulty any more. As opposed to C1, learners on this Level succeed in reading with ease, texts that are very difficult regarding content and/or language, and which represent a challenge even for educated native speakers.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Very simple everyday conversations or exchanges are feasible when well-learnt short phrases or single sentences are used, and if the other person does his/her best to make the conversation a success. Linguistic correctness plays a lesser role here. Facial expression and gestures are much used to support what is said.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: The situation governing an interaction, and the topic, need to be familiar to speakers on this Level; spoken interaction will be very short, and will serve to exchange the most essential information only. Simple language structures and the relevant vocabulary are used correctly in the sense that the meaning of contributions becomes clear. As compared to A1, a wider vocabulary and more linguistic structures are at learners’ disposal, to cover a wider range of topics.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: In many familiar everyday or work-related situations, speakers can interact and communicate spontaneously about various topics, and contribute actively to an exchange. Mostly they succeed in communicating the essentials, even though mistakes or pauses may occur. Compared to Level A2, vocabulary and linguistic structures are much more extensive, so that a larger range of topics can be discussed with no preparation.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: In exchanges with native speakers (among others), on many different topics that are of importance in our society, learners can interact, reply to arguments, and uphold their own viewpoint with clarity. As opposed to Level B1, topics go beyond immediate everyday situations; vocabulary and linguistic structures at learners’ disposal are of such great range that a speaker’s own opinion can be expressed clearly and distinctly. Speakers succeed (more or less) in adapting what they say, to the other person or persons (register).

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Exchanges in all areas of personal and working life can be conducted very spontaneously and fluently. As opposed to B2, learners can adapt even better to the other person or persons, i. e. learners know exactly what to say to whom in what situation, and in what way. Vocabulary and linguistic structures are so extensive and can be used so precisely that an exchange can be kept going with no noticeable interruption.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: No effort is involved in conducting formal or informal exchanges spontaneously, with the most various interlocutors, and on the greatest possible variety of topics. As opposed to C1, more idioms and colloquial phrases are used: all in all, learners’ language resembles that of educated native speakers.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Speakers have a number of simple everyday expressions by heart, to communicate elementary information about themselves and others.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Speakers can give information about a few topics of everyday life using several phrases or sentences. The vocabulary required is known, and simple linguistic structures are used correctly, in the sense that the meaning of statements is clear even though elementary mistakes may occur. As opposed to Level A1, speakers can use coherent sentences to talk about things and matters present, past and future.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Speakers can speak in a coherent way about familiar topics such as everyday occurrences, topics related to training, to the world of work and to travelling; they can also give reasons for viewpoints. For these purposes they dispose of sufficient vocabulary. They pause sometimes, need to reformulate, and make mistakes: however, the intended meaning of statements comes across. As opposed to Level A2, vocabulary and linguistic structures are much more extensive, so that a wider range of topics can be covered, even without preparation.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Longer units of speech about a large number of topics (concerning a speaker’s personal or working life) contain important details and are clearly structured, or clearly highlight the speaker‘s own point of view. As opposed to Level B1, spoken production is spontaneous and fluent; vocabulary and linguistic structures are extensive enough for speakers to present topics in a well structured way, and to argue their own viewpoint logically and coherently. There are hardly any elementary mistakes any more that might distort meaning.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Topics in the most varied subject areas can be presented with such linguistic precision that audiences are clear about context and connections. As opposed to Level B2, speakers can use linguistic means that make quite clear the textual structure of complex thought and speech; linguistic ways and means that highlight certain aspects; and that round off a contribution with an appropriate conclusion. Speakers also have a range of idiomatic and colloquial phrases, and can well adapt to relevant addressees.

table.name: block_desp_niveau_texte
table.title: Oral contributions of all kinds are developed and presented in so interesting a way that recipients find it easy to follow even difficult lines of thought and to remember details. As opposed to Level C1, learners have reached a linguistic and intellectual level that is usually attained by educated native speakers only.
